text: Steven yeah, so a traditional ETF has like an authorized participant, and those. So those units are sort of created as the customer or the buyer wants to buy or sell that product. There's no redemption mechanism to sort of create price parity between the assets that are held in the trust and the price of that trust. And so closing funds often trade at a premium or discount based on supply demand characteristics, in a way that a traditional ETF doesn't. And that was good for grayscale and in a sense, for the market for a while, when it was the only product in the market in the US that would allow you easily to get access to bitcoin in a brokerage account.

speaker: F
text: I think the biggest thing that I'm watching right now is the infrastructure business building up around bitcoin. When you think about what the SEC has sort of done to the crypto market broadly, is they've made it clear that bitcoin and maybe ethereum are probably the only safe places for institutions to deploy capital where there's no risk that they'll be called securities later. There's no risk where their favorite exchanges will pull those listings and make it impossible to trade them and get liquidity. And so if you want to make heavy duty investments in the infrastructure layer beyond the protocol itself, bitcoin is probably the safest place to do that. And that's probably why you're seeing the hash rate go nuts, right? The hash rate has exploded higher for bitcoin over the last six months, even as the price continues to be more than 50% below all time highs. And part of that is investments that were made prior to this most recent drawdown. Remember, these are long lead items, like people are buying land building data centers, they're plugging in machines that sometimes take six or twelve months to arrive. They have to buy transformers. They have to build substations. And so one of the things that is interesting about bitcoin is it has this physical world infrastructure component. And the best analogy I can think of for this is the Internet data center business in 2002, 2003. You think about a company like Equinix, which today is one of the largest Internet data center providers. That was a $3 stock in 2002. At one point over the last five years, it was like an eight or $900 stock. And it was really a binary bet on, would the Internet be bigger? And so if more people want to use the Internet, you need more infrastructure to more bandwidth in order for the consumer Internet to thrive. I think the same things going to happen with bitcoin where these bitcoin miners, I call them bitcoin infrastructure providers or bitcoin data center providers are going to continue to have to grow if bitcoin is going to grow. Because unlike these proof of stake protocols, proof of work does require real world infrastructure and real world energy for it to work. And if you look at the stocks this year, a bunch of the leading bitcoin mining stocks are up 200% to 300%. Quietly, none of the big tiger cub hedge funds, none of the traditional asset managers are talking about this space. And yet the stocks are outperforming Nvidia year to date. So I think it's a space to watch going forward.

text: Steven? Because thats just not the way that traditional asset managers think. Its not the way the regulatory superstructure works. Exchanges should be separate from asset managers, should be separate from custody, should be separate from clearing. And one of the problems in crypto native businesses is they've tried to do the full stack themselves, which means there's no separation and there's a lot of conflicts of interest and there's a lot of risk to the end depositor and the end customer. And so I think Blackrock intends to operate as they do in traditional markets here and not be their own custodian, because that's just not the way to keep customers safe.

There'll be some larger miners buying smaller miners. And you did see some situations where lenders who didn't get paid back on miner financing actually foreclosed on the machines. It sort of became self miners through the backdoor. Instead of just buying machines and building buildings and plugging them in and becoming a self miner, they lent money to miners. Those miners defaulted. They took those miners and plugged them in somewhere else and essentially became a self miner. So you'll see some of that, you'll see some mergers of equals. And then in the long term, I think you'll see traditional energy companies coming in and wanting to buy bitcoin miners to create other ways to monetize existing power assets that they have. When you look at the field of large scale, publicly traded bitcoin miners say most of them do not control the underlying power production. That's the area where they stop. They do everything once the power is on the other side of the wall. They build the buildings, they plug in the machines, they monetize that, that hash and turn into bitcoin. But they don't own the natural gas, they don't own the wind or the solar. They're sometimes doing jvs with those companies, right? And they're large customers of those companies and they're somewhat location agnostic. They can throttle up or down. Right. That's one of the interesting things about miners. Unlike an aluminum smelting plant where you can't stop the process at six out of ten without losing the work, bitcoin miners, because it's a probabilistic process, you can stop and start at sort of any point. And that's exactly what they're doing in Texas over the last week or two. With the temperatures really high, theyre curtailing and getting paid by the grid for creating that grid stability by removing that load, removing that peak demand. But then they can also be buyers of last resort and large scale buyers at other times when the power is sort of ubiquitous and cheap.
